Inspiring quote by @cwebber –

'Christine Lemmer-Webber is the lead author of the 2018 ActivityPub standard, based on prior work led by Evan Prodromou on another service called pump.io. Lemmer-Webber tells Ars that, when developing the ActivityPub standard, "We were like the only standards group at the W3C that didn't have corporate involvement... She felt that ActivityPub was a success for the idea of decentralization even before its multi-million user bump over the last few months. @futurebird@sauropods.win this is related to why I refuse to use the word ‘right’ to mean correct because internally it connotes incorrect, far away over there, the bad direction

The word ‘right’ is overloaded, but not only overloaded, overloaded with contradictions – left is the comfortable ‘home’ direction, right is the alien direction, yet ‘right’ is commonly used to mean good and okay and correct, but in my mind it connotes exactly the opposite, so I’ve adopted ‘right’ as the direction, the counterpart of ‘left’ the direction, and distinctly, ‘correct’ and ‘incorrect’ to mean only those things – so I’ve almost entirely removed the meaning of ‘right’ meaning anything to do with correct/incorrectness (apart from typing this, which has diluted it a bit)

I don’t approve of overloading words – just invent new ones, I’m sure there’s plenty spare we haven’t discovered yet #Typography

@jmateosg @mattsclancy I would love to see more detail on an argument that a decline in novelty is associated with less inclusivity.

Ideologies of novelty are a common reason that research by non-white, non-Western scholars is dismissed as "applied" rather than "basic/theoretical." title: Long read | Debunking myths on links between austerity and Brexit

last_post.content:
A great example of some quite blatant misreading of data is posted below.

This was in 2019. Rob Ford claimed that classic #Brexit voters and supporters - UKIP voters - wanting more #austerity

This is just false. As I explain at length here (https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/brexit/2019/10/17/long-read-debunking-myths-on-links-between-austerity-and-brexit/)
#UKIP voters, to a tiny extent disliked #austerity a bit less than the rest.

Misreading data and quick analysis can lead to such wrong conclusions producing noise that benefited those behind #austerity and #Brexit project.

Today our team launched the @astro rebuild of https://mijnvraagovercorona.nl 🎉

Originally the website was built using Next.js with a lighthouse performance score of ~73. Now we score 99:
LCP 3.8s -> 1s
TTI 5.4s -> 3.3s
TBT 420ms -> 80ms
CLS 0.127 -> 0.008.
Tweaking of 3rd party scripts should get us the full 💯💯💯💯

With the rebuild we could also focus on some accessibility painpoints. It's not perfect yet, but we're actively working on it. 🙌🏼

#frontend #astro #nextjs #performance #accessibility

title: Why high-profile journals have more retractions - Nature

last_post.content: (Singling out CNS as these are the "high prestige" journals, even if it has been shown before that they actually have a higher retraction rate https://www.nature.com/articles/nature.2014.15951)

This post on not sending people to mars https://idlewords.com/2023/1/why_not_mars.htm reminded me that there's this trail of CNS papers that the community decided are BS, but still linger without any notice or retraction. Like this one on a 250 million year old, viable bacterium https://www.nature.com/articles/35038060 or DNA from dinosaur bones https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.7973705 . There's a refuting technical comment on the latter (https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.7761839), but it's not mentioned or linked from the original paper
